awd_titl_txt: Characterizing Mesoscale Thermospheric F-region Winds Associated with Quasi-steady and Transient Nightside Auroral Arcs
awd_abstract_narration:
The magnetosphere is a leading source of auroral energy and momentum transport within the high-latitude thermosphere. Winds at these so-called 'meso' scales play a crucial role in the transport processes, yet have never been systematically characterized due to lack of observations. The PIs will statistically catalog mesoscale F-region (150-600 km above Earth?s surface) wind occurrences, structure and evolution. The proposed efforts leverage substantial NSF assets to lay the ground for inferring winds from auroral morphology. This work will inform efforts to model magnetosphere-ionosphere-thermosphere interaction at mesoscales. Its broader impacts include support for young scientists and a female postdoc, and publicizing auroral events. 

The team will categorize mesoscale winds according to different auroral arcs and geomagnetic and solar conditions. They will synergize European satellite wind data with several datasets that are closely spaced and/or observe common volumes over Alaska and western Canada. The spatial scales and direction of thermospheric winds provide information on underlying forcing, and serve as indicators of the efficiency of ionosphere-thermosphere coupling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aims to understand upper thermospheric wind structures embedded in the global twin-cell circulation pattern at high latitudes. Structures of interest include winds associated with individual auroral forms, substorms, and subauroral polarization streams. The project was motivated by the fact that magnetospheric forcing often occurs in a spatially localized and temporally variable manner at high latitudes. Such intense energy input should drive a characteristic wind perturbation whose properties are closely associated with auroras/ionospheric flows. The project was conducted using simultaneous measurements from the NSF-supported Scanning Doppler Imagers, THEMIS all-sky imagers, and radars with common field-of-views in Alaska. The project has yielded series of publications, and the major science outcomes are:

 

1.     Around individual auroral forms, winds exhibit distinct spatial structures, appearing as channels, vortices, and reversals. Such structures are consistent with the structures of the plasma flows associated with the auroras. Winds exhibit a temporal evolution very similar to the plasma flows and reach maximum perturbations only <~20 min after the flows.

2.     During substorm growth phase, winds exhibit the classical two-cell global circulation pattern but of an intensified speed. After substorm onset, the zonal component of the winds is strongly suppressed around midnight, consistent with previous studies of plasma convection, whereas far from midnight the two-cell circulation of winds is enhanced. Both the pre- and post-onset enhancements are ≥ 100 m/s above the quite time value, and the post-onset enhancement occurs over a broader latitude and local-time area than the pre-onset one. 

3.     During non-storm subauroral polarization streams (SAPS), winds at times are enhanced in the westward direction in the dusk-midnight sector, but not always. The occurrence of the westward winds varies with AE index, plasma content in the trough, and local time. The latitudinally averaged wind speed varies from 60 to 160 m/s, and is statistically 21% of the plasma. These westward winds also shift to lower latitude with increasing AE and increasing MLT.

4.     We also developed a new method, which is weighted windowed time-lagged correlation (weighted WTLC) method, for calculating how fast wind respond to changes in ionospheric plasma convection. This method provides a time evolution of the wind response time and considers the effects of all thermospheric forces, while previous methods were only capable of one or the other. 

 

The above results have been disseminated in peer-reviewed journals as well as conferences and workshops.

 

The project supported a female graduate student, Katherine Davidson, for her Ph.D. thesis research. Katherine presented her results in several workshops and conferences, such as CEDAR workshop, GEM workshop, AGU Fall meetings, and received positive feedback. She was selected for the 2nd Student Poster Presentation Prize. She also received NASA FINNEST fellowship and UCAR Newkirk fellowship in recognition of her existing accomplishments and future potential. Katherine is expected to receive her PhD degree by the end of 2024.

The project supported the PI to develop a new course “Magnetospheric and Ionospheric Physics” in the department of space science at University of Alabama in Huntsville. The main objective of this course is to introduce the basic observational facts and theoretical concepts of magnetospheric and ionospheric physics at the graduate level, so that graduate students of space physics can have the basic knowledge and tools to conduct their research.
